title: GO-FAR (Good Outcome Following Attempted Resuscitation) Score
description: Predicts survival to discharge with good neurological outcome after in-hospital cardiac arrest. Uses 13 pre-arrest variables to stratify patients into risk categories for shared decision-making regarding resuscitation preferences.

parameters.name: age_category
parameters.description: Patient age category with increasing points for older age groups

parameters.name: neurologically_intact
parameters.description: Patient neurologically intact at admission (CPC score of 1)

parameters.name: major_trauma
parameters.description: Major trauma as primary diagnosis or significant contributing factor

parameters.name: acute_stroke
parameters.description: Acute stroke as primary diagnosis or significant contributing factor

parameters.name: medical_noncardiac_diagnosis
parameters.description: Medical non-cardiac diagnosis as primary reason for admission

parameters.name: hepatic_insufficiency
parameters.description: Hepatic insufficiency (cirrhosis, acute hepatitis, or liver failure)

parameters.name: skilled_nursing_facility
parameters.description: Admitted from skilled nursing facility or long-term care facility

parameters.name: hypotension_hypoperfusion
parameters.description: Hypotension or hypoperfusion requiring vasopressors or inotropes

parameters.name: respiratory_insufficiency
parameters.description: Respiratory insufficiency requiring mechanical ventilation or supplemental oxygen

result.name: go_far_score
result.description: Total GO-FAR score calculated from weighted clinical variables

ranges.interpretation: Above average probability of survival with good neurological outcome (>15%). Resuscitation generally appropriate and should be discussed with patient/family.
Average probability of survival with good neurological outcome (3-15%). Individualized decision-making recommended based on patient values and preferences.
Low probability of survival with good neurological outcome (1-3%). Consider discussing limitations of resuscitation with patient/family.
Very low probability of survival with good neurological outcome (<1%). Strong consideration for do-not-attempt-resuscitation (DNAR) order after appropriate discussion.

references: Ebell MH, Jang W, Shen Y, Geocadin RG. Get With the Guidelines-Resuscitation Investigators. Development and validation of the Good Outcome Following Attempted Resuscitation (GO-FAR) score to predict neurologically intact survival after in-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation. JAMA Intern Med. 2013;173(20):1872-8. doi: 10.1001/jamainternmed.2013.10037.

Piscator E, Hedberg P, Göransson K, Djarv T. Prearrest prediction of survival with good neurologic recovery among in-hospital cardiac arrest patients. Resuscitation. 2018;128:63-69. doi: 10.1016/j.resuscitation.2018.05.006.

Perman SM, Stanton E, Soar J, et al. Location of in-hospital cardiac arrest in the United States—variability in event rate and outcomes. J Am Heart Assoc. 2016;5(10):e003638. doi: 10.1161/JAHA.116.003638.
formula: Sum of weighted points from 13 clinical variables: Age (0-11 pts), Neurologically intact (-15 pts), Major trauma (+10 pts), Acute stroke (+8 pts), Metastatic/hematologic cancer (+7 pts), Septicemia (+7 pts), Medical non-cardiac diagnosis (+7 pts), Hepatic insufficiency (+6 pts), Skilled nursing facility admission (+6 pts), Hypotension/hypoperfusion (+5 pts), Renal insufficiency (+4 pts), Respiratory insufficiency (+4 pts), Pneumonia (+1 pt)
notes: Score ranges from -15 to +50 points (theoretical maximum ~47 points in practice)
Developed for in-hospital cardiac arrest prediction, not applicable to out-of-hospital arrests
Should be used as part of shared decision-making, not as sole determinant of resuscitation status
Neurologically intact survival defined as Cerebral Performance Category (CPC) score of 1 at discharge
Variables should be assessed at time of hospital admission or current clinical status
Consider patient and family values and preferences in addition to probability estimates
